questions.question_text:
You created a virtual cloud network (VCN) with three private subnets. Two of the subnets contain application servers and the third subnet contains a DB System.
The application requires a shared file system so you have provisioned one using the file storage service (FSS).
You also created the corresponding mount target in one of the application subnets. The VCN security lists are properly configured so that both application servers and the DB system can access the file system. The security team determines that the DB System should have read-only access to the file system.
What change should you make to satisfy this requirement?

discussion.content: A is correct
Please ignore my previous comment, the correct answer is "A" , I came back after reviewing the videos and notes to take my initial answer back.
A IS CORRECT

Selected Answer: A
NFS export options enable you to create more granular access control than is possible using just security list rules to limit VCN access. You can use NFS export options to specify access levels for IP addresses or CIDR blocks connecting to file systems through exports in a mount target. Access can be restricted so that each clientâ€™s file system is inaccessible and invisible to the other, providing better security controls in multi-tenant environments.

Using NFS export option access controls, you can limit clients' ability to connect to the file system and view or write data. For example, if you want to allow clients to consume but not update resources in your file system, you can set access to Read Only. You can also reduce client root access to your file systems and map specified User IDs (UIDs) and Group IDs (GIDs) to an anonymous UID/GID of your choice. For more information about how NFS export options work with other security layers,
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Tasks/exportoptions2.htm
A is correct
A correct
Answer is A
I would go with C.

choices.A: Create an NFS export option that allows READ_ONLY access where the source is the CIDR range of the DB System subnet.
choices.B: Modify the security list associated with the subnet where the mount target resides. Change the ingress rules corresponding to the DB System subnet to be stateless.
choices.C: Create an instance principal for the DB System. Write an Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy that allows the instance principal read-only access to the file storage service.
choices.D: Connect via SSH to one of the application servers where the file system has been mounted. Use the Unix command chmod to change permissions on the file system directory, allowing the database user read only access.

questions.question_text:
Your company uses the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Object Storage service to share large data sets with its data science team. The data science team consists of 20 people who work from offices in Washington, D.C., and Tokyo. While working in these offices, employees are assigned an IP address from the public IP range 129.146.31.0/27
Which two steps should you take to ensure that the Object Storage bucket used in this scenario was only accessible from these office locations? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Correct Answers are A,D.
I just think that answer "A" is missing the rest of the word, it should be "CorpNetwork".
The rest of the answers just don't make sense.
Admins pretty please review the answers for this one. 
Thanks.

comments.content: I think that AD are correct, however there is a name mismatch between both

discussion.content: AD are correct

Selected Answer: AD
think that AD is correct

Selected Answer: AD
Introduction to Network Sources
A network source is a set of defined IP addresses. The IP addresses can be public IP addresses or IP addresses from VCNs within your tenancy. After you create the network source, you can reference it in policy or in your tenancy's authentication settings to control access based on the originating IP address.

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Tasks/managingnetworksources.htm

this means that AD are correct.
1.D. make a network name
2.A. Make a policy.

Selected Answer: DF
I would go with D and F
I'd go with A,D

comments.content: Standard CIDR should be /16 on the OCI side , not on the Customer end.

discussion.content: Answer is C and E.. as per the standard CIDR should be /16

comments.content: Also the question starts with "Which two steps ..." . That confirms D and A as the correct answer because A follows D as a 2-step solution

agree:
To restrict access to requests made from a set of IP addresses, do the following:

1. Create a network source that specifies the allowed IP addresses.
2. Write a policy that uses the network source variable in a condition

discussion.content:
What would be the point in creating a network source name and then not creating a rule to use it?
What is the relevance of creating a PAR, since the requirement is to limit the accessibility of the files to a certain specific location (identified via the endpoint's ip addresses?

choices.F: Write an IAM policy that includes the conditional statement where request.region = 129.146.31.0/27
choices.D: Create a Network Source named CorpNetwork with a CIDR block of 129.146.31.0/27
choices.C: Create a pre-authenticated request for each data set and only share with the data science team via email
choices.E: Create a Network Source named CorpNetwork with a CIDR block of 129.146.0.0/16
choices.B: Set the bucket visibility to public and only share the URL with the data science team via email
choices.A: Write an IAM policy that includes the conditional statement where request.networkSource.name = CorpNet

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Data Guard implementation in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) bare metal and virtual machine database systems?

choices.A: Both database systems must be in the same compartment.
choices.C: Primary and standby databases must be in the same OCI region.
choices.D: Database systems need not be the same shape type (e.g., primary database can be a virtual machine, and standby database a bare metal shape, and vice versa).
choices.B: Primary and standby database versions and editions need not be identical.

discussion.content:
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Tasks/usingdataguard.htm :

Requirement details are as follows:
Both DB systems must be in the same compartment.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Requirement details are as follows:

Both DB systems must be in the same compartment.
The DB systems must be the same shape type (for example, if the shape of the primary database is a virtual machine, then the shape of the standby database can be any other virtual machine shape).

A is correct.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/dbcs/doc/use-oracle-data-guard-db-system.html#GUID-C85CEBE5-57A4-4AC7-BEC5-A4FDCB6DBEC0
A is correct.

Answer is A because both primary and standby has to be in same compartment and need to share the same shape.

So B is not correct and also c cannot be the option as we can create standby in different regions to achieve HA and D is wrong
A is correct by the explanation is here : https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Tasks/usingdataguard.htm

questions.question_text:
Your application front end consists of several Oracle Cloud Infrastructure compute instances behind a public load balancer. You have configured the load balancer to perform health checks on these instances.
What will happen if an instance fails to pass the configured health checks?

choices.A: The instance is terminated automatically by the load balancer.
choices.C: The instance is replaced automatically by the load balancer.
choices.B: The load balancer stops sending traffic to that instance.
choices.D: The instance is taken out of the backend set by the load balancer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B should be the correct answer

I THINK D
If a server fails the health check, the load balancer takes the server temporarily out of rotation. If the server subsequently passes the health check, the load balancer returns it to the rotation.
B is the one.

It should be B.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Balance/Tasks/editinghealthcheck.htm
If a server fails the health check, the load balancer takes the server temporarily out of rotation. If the server subsequently passes the health check, the load balancer returns it to the rotation.
B is correct

Answer is correct. 
Health Check is a test performed on different levels to confirm the availability of the backend servers, backend sets and overall Load Balancer.
If a backend server fails the backend set and the overall Load Balancer will still appear as healthy. 
The LB will route the traffic to the healthy servers.
